metadata.description: Iconic street food dishes found in Singapore's hawker centers - the heart of Singaporean food culture

recipes.name: Soy Sauce Chicken (Si Yau Kai)
recipes.description: A beloved Cantonese dish popular in Singapore, featuring whole chicken gently poached in a fragrant soy sauce-based broth. Famous at hawker stalls like Hawker Chan and Chew Kee, this dish is prized for its tender, juicy meat and glossy, savory skin.
recipes.imageAttribution: Photo by Terry Wong, The Food Canon (https://www.foodcanon.com/2011/05/soy-sauce-chicken-si-yau-kai.html). Used with permission or under fair use for educational/non-commercial recipe illustration. If you wish to use this image for commercial purposes, please contact the original author.

poaching liquid.optional: dried orange peel, liquorice stick, bay leaf

steps: Rub the chicken all over with salt, then rinse and pat dry.
In a large pot or rice cooker, heat a little oil and fry the ginger, garlic, spring onions, star anise, and cinnamon until fragrant.
Add light soy sauce, dark soy sauce, rock sugar, white peppercorns, and water. Simmer for 30 minutes to develop the flavors.
Lower the chicken gently into the simmering sauce, breast side down. Add more water if needed to submerge the chicken.
Poach gently (72-80°C) for 60-90 minutes, turning occasionally for even color. Do not boil vigorously.
When cooked, remove the chicken and let it rest. Optionally, thicken some of the sauce with cornstarch for drizzling.
Chop the chicken into serving pieces. Arrange on a platter, garnish with cilantro and spring onions, and serve with sliced cucumber and steamed rice. Drizzle with sauce.
tips: Use a good quality soy sauce for best flavor.
Poach gently to keep the meat juicy and the skin intact.
The leftover sauce can be reused for another batch or to braise eggs and tofu.
Serve with chili sauce for an authentic Singaporean touch.
recipes.source: Adapted from The Food Canon, Chew Kee, and Hawker Chan recipes.
recipes.origin: Cantonese in origin, Soy Sauce Chicken is a staple at Singaporean hawker centers, with famous renditions at Hawker Chan (the world's first Michelin-starred hawker) and Chew Kee.

recipes.name: Paper-Wrapped Chicken (纸包鸡)
recipes.description: A Cantonese-origin dish popular in Singapore, featuring marinated chicken pieces wrapped in parchment and deep-fried or baked. The result is juicy, aromatic chicken infused with soy, sesame oil, and Chinese wine.
steps: Mix chicken with all marinade ingredients, ginger, and spring onion. Marinate for at least 1 hour (overnight best).
Place a portion of chicken and aromatics in the center of each paper square. Fold and seal tightly into a parcel.
Heat oil in a wok or deep pot to 180°C (if deep frying). Fry parcels for 4-5 minutes until golden and puffed. Alternatively, bake at 200°C for 15-18 minutes.
Drain and serve parcels hot. Diners open the paper to enjoy the aromatic, juicy chicken.
tips: Use parchment or greaseproof paper, not waxed paper.
Marinate chicken overnight for best flavor.
Can be baked for a lighter version.
recipes.source: Adapted from The MeatMen, Rasa Malaysia, and Singaporean Cantonese home cooks.
recipes.origin: Cantonese community in Singapore; a popular zi char and banquet dish.

recipes.name: Singapore Hokkien Mee
recipes.description: A classic Singapore hawker dish of stir-fried yellow noodles and rice vermicelli, prawns, squid, and pork belly, braised in a rich homemade prawn stock. Served with sambal and lime for a true hawker experience.
steps: Peel the prawn heads. In a hot wok, add 1 tbsp oil and fry the prawn heads until fragrant. Add the fried prawn heads to the chicken stock and boil for 30 minutes.
Add the pork belly to the stock and boil for 15 minutes. Remove the pork belly, let cool, and slice into strips.

In a hot wok, add 1 tbsp oil and fry the garlic until fragrant. Add the eggs and scramble. Then add the yellow noodles and rice vermicelli, frying for a few minutes until the noodles just begin to sear.
Pour in all the prawn stock, followed by the prawns and squid. Braise the noodles for 2-3 minutes. When everything is cooked through, add the chives. Stir to combine.
Season with fish sauce, white pepper, and sesame oil. Serve immediately with lime wedges and sambal chili on the side.
tips: Homemade prawn stock is the secret to making this dish extra flavorful. Simmer prawn heads with chicken stock for 30 minutes.
Use a mix of yellow noodles and thick rice vermicelli for the best texture.
Do not over-braise the noodles; 2-3 minutes is enough to keep the seafood tender.
Serve with sambal and lime for an authentic hawker experience.
recipes.origin: Singapore; a signature hawker dish with roots in Fujian, China, adapted by local hawkers.

recipes.name: Char Kway Teow
recipes.description: A legendary Singaporean and Malaysian hawker dish of stir-fried flat rice noodles with prawns, Chinese sausage, fish cake, egg, bean sprouts, and garlic chives, all tossed in a savory-sweet sauce and cooked over high heat for signature wok hei.
steps: Mix all sauce ingredients together in a bowl and set aside.
Warm the rice noodles until pliable and gently separate. Do not boil or soak in hot water.
Heat lard and 1 tbsp oil in a wok or large skillet over high heat until smoking. Add prawns and cook for 30 seconds.
Add garlic and stir for 10 seconds. Add noodles and toss gently to coat with oil.
Add Chinese sausage and fish cake, toss gently. Add bean sprouts and garlic chives, toss again.
Push everything to one side, add remaining oil, then add eggs and cook, stirring, until mostly set. Chop up roughly with a wooden spoon.
Pour sauce over noodles, then toss to disperse sauce through the noodles. Pause between tosses to allow noodles to caramelize on the edges.
Serve immediately with chili paste or sambal on the side.
tips: Use fresh rice noodles for best texture and less breakage.
Cook in small batches for best wok hei (charred aroma).
Do not over-handle the noodles to avoid breakage.
Chinese sausage and fish cake are essential for authentic flavor, but can be substituted if needed.
Serve with extra chili paste or sambal for a spicy kick.
recipes.origin: Singapore and Malaysia; a street food classic beloved for its smoky flavor and rich mix of ingredients.

recipes.name: Singapore Carrot Cake (Chai Tow Kway)
recipes.description: A beloved Singapore hawker dish of pan-fried radish cake cubes, stir-fried with eggs, garlic, preserved radish, and scallions. Available in white (savory) or black (with sweet soy sauce) versions.
preparation: Peel and grate the daikon radish. Boil in water until translucent, then strain.
Mix rice flour, tapioca flour, salt, and chicken stock until smooth. Stir in cooked radish and garlic.
Pour into a greased pan and steam for 1 hour until set. Cool and chill overnight.
Cut chilled radish cake into cubes. Fry with garlic, chai poh, and scallions. Add eggs and sauces (white or black version). Stir-fry until eggs are set and cake is crisp.
Garnish with more scallions. Serve hot.
tips: Use a nonstick pan for best results.
For black version, use a good quality dark sweet soy sauce (not kecap manis).
recipes.source: Adapted from Serious Eats, Rasa Malaysia, and NLB Singapore Infopedia.
steps: Peel and grate the daikon radish. Boil in water until translucent, then strain.
Mix rice flour, tapioca flour, salt, and chicken stock until smooth. Stir in cooked radish and garlic.
Pour into a greased pan and steam for 1 hour until set. Cool and chill overnight.
Cut chilled radish cake into cubes. Fry with garlic, chai poh, and scallions. Add eggs and sauces (white or black version). Stir-fry until eggs are set and cake is crisp.
Garnish with more scallions. Serve hot.

recipes.name: Oyster Omelette (Orh Luak)
recipes.description: A classic Teochew hawker dish of eggs, oysters, and a crispy-gooey batter made from sweet potato and rice flour. Served with tangy sambal chili sauce.
preparation: Mix all batter ingredients and set aside.
Beat eggs with fish sauce and pepper.
Heat oil in a nonstick pan. Pour in batter to form a thin layer. Fry until edges are crisp and center is gooey.
Add half the eggs, let set, then flip. Add more oil, pour in remaining eggs, and fry until set.
Add oysters, garlic, and spring onions. Stir-fry briefly. Serve with cilantro and sambal dip.
tips: Cook one serving at a time for best texture.
Do not overcook oysters; they should remain plump and juicy.
recipes.source: Adapted from The Burning Kitchen, What To Cook Today, and Nomadette.
steps: Mix all batter ingredients and set aside.
Beat eggs with fish sauce and pepper.
Heat oil in a nonstick pan. Pour in batter to form a thin layer. Fry until edges are crisp and center is gooey.
Add half the eggs, let set, then flip. Add more oil, pour in remaining eggs, and fry until set.
Add oysters, garlic, and spring onions. Stir-fry briefly. Serve with cilantro and sambal dip.

recipes.name: Chicken Satay (Singapore Style)
recipes.description: Juicy, smoky grilled chicken skewers marinated in lemongrass, turmeric, and spices. Served with classic peanut sauce, cucumber, and onions.
preparation: Blend marinade ingredients into a paste. Marinate chicken for at least 6 hours or overnight.
Thread chicken onto soaked bamboo skewers. Grill over charcoal or grill pan, basting with oil, until charred and cooked through.
For peanut sauce: sauté garlic, shallots, and chili paste in oil. Add ground peanuts, coconut milk, tamarind water, sugar, and salt. Simmer until thickened.
Serve satay with peanut sauce, cucumber, onion, and rice cakes.
tips: Marinate chicken overnight for best flavor.
Use a mix of thighs and breast for juicier satay.
recipes.source: Adapted from Rasa Malaysia, Serious Eats, and Singapore Local Favourites.
steps: Blend marinade ingredients into a paste. Marinate chicken for at least 6 hours or overnight.
Thread chicken onto soaked bamboo skewers. Grill over charcoal or grill pan, basting with oil, until charred and cooked through.
For peanut sauce: sauté garlic, shallots, and chili paste in oil. Add ground peanuts, coconut milk, tamarind water, sugar, and salt. Simmer until thickened.
Serve satay with peanut sauce, cucumber, onion, and rice cakes.

recipes.name: Hainanese Chicken Rice
recipes.description: Singapore’s iconic poached chicken and fragrant rice, served with chili sauce, ginger, and dark soy.

sauces.chili sauce: to serve (blend red chilies, garlic, ginger, lime, chicken stock, salt)
sauces.ginger sauce: to serve (blend ginger, spring onion, oil, salt)

steps: Rub chicken with salt, rinse, and place in a large pot with spring onions, ginger, and garlic. Cover with water, bring to a boil, then simmer gently for 40-50 minutes until cooked.
Transfer chicken to ice water to cool and firm up the skin. Chop into serving pieces.
For rice: Heat chicken fat/oil in a pan, sauté garlic, ginger, and pandan leaves until fragrant. Add rice, stir to coat, then add chicken stock and salt. Cook as usual.
Prepare chili and ginger sauces by blending ingredients with a little chicken stock.
To serve: Arrange chicken on a platter, garnish with cucumber and cilantro. Serve with rice, sauces, and a bowl of chicken broth.
tips: Use good quality chicken for best results.
Poach gently for juicy, tender meat and smooth skin.
Save the poaching liquid for soup and sauces.
recipes.source: Adapted from Singapore hawker and home cook recipes.
recipes.origin: Hainanese Chicken Rice is Singapore’s national dish, beloved at hawker centers and restaurants alike.

recipes.name: Fishball Noodles
recipes.description: A beloved Singapore hawker dish of springy noodles tossed in savory sauce, served with bouncy fishballs, fishcake, and vegetables. Can be enjoyed dry or in soup.
steps: Prepare soup: Simmer stock with garlic and white pepper. Add fishballs and fishcake, cook until fishballs float.
Blanch noodles and bean sprouts. For dry version, toss noodles with sauce ingredients in a bowl.
Top noodles with fishballs, fishcake, bean sprouts, lettuce, spring onions, and fried shallots.
Serve with a bowl of hot soup on the side.
tips: Use fresh, bouncy fishballs for best texture.
Adjust chili and vinegar to taste for the dry version.
Mee pok (flat) and mee kia (thin) are the most common noodle choices.
recipes.source: Adapted from Singapore hawker and home cook recipes.
recipes.origin: Fishball Noodles is a staple at Singapore hawker centers, enjoyed by all ages.

ingredient_breakdown.ingredient: mee pok or mee kia (egg noodles)

recipes.name: Yong Tau Foo
recipes.description: A healthy and customizable hawker favorite: tofu, vegetables, and beancurd skin stuffed with fish paste, served in a light broth with noodles or rice.

stuffing items.bittergourd: 1, sliced into thick rings, seeds removed

steps: Make Fish Paste: Chop fish fillet finely, then pound or process into a sticky paste. Add salt, pepper, cornstarch, and ice water gradually until smooth and bouncy.

Stuff Vegetables: Pat dry tofu, vegetables, and beancurd skin. Stuff each piece with fish paste (use wet hands or a spoon). For beancurd skin, spread fish paste, roll up, and seal with a little water.
Prepare Soup: Simmer stock with garlic (and soybeans if using) for 20 minutes. Season with salt and pepper.

Cook Yong Tau Foo: Bring a pot of water to a gentle simmer. Poach stuffed items (except beancurd skin) until fish paste is cooked and floats (about 5-7 minutes). For beancurd skin rolls, steam or pan-fry until golden and cooked through.
Serve: Arrange noodles in bowls. Top with cooked yong tau foo pieces. Ladle hot soup over. Garnish with fried shallots, spring onions, and serve with chili and sweet sauce.
tips: Use fresh mackerel for the best fish paste texture.
You can add stuffed mushrooms, tofu puffs, or other favorite vegetables.
For a dry version, toss noodles with sauce and serve soup on the side.
recipes.source: Adapted from Singapore hawker and home cook recipes.
recipes.origin: Yong Tau Foo is a Hakka Chinese dish, now a staple at Singapore hawker centers.

ingredient_breakdown.ingredient: white fish fillet (e.g., mackerel or tenggiri)
yellow noodles or bee hoon (rice vermicelli)

recipes.name: Lor Mee (Non-Vegetarian)
recipes.description: A beloved Singapore hawker dish: thick yellow noodles in a savory, starchy gravy, topped with braised pork belly, egg, ngoh hiang, and condiments.
steps: Prepare Gravy: Simmer pork bones, garlic, star anise, and cinnamon in water for 1 hour. Strain stock, return to pot. Add soy sauces, oyster sauce, five-spice, pepper, salt, and sugar. Thicken with cornstarch slurry, simmer until glossy and thick. Add vinegar if desired.
Prepare Toppings: Braise pork belly as above, then slice. Prepare ngoh hiang, fish cake, wantons, and eggs as desired.

Assemble: Blanch noodles and bean sprouts, place in bowls. Ladle hot gravy over. Top with pork belly, ngoh hiang, fish cake, egg, and other toppings. Garnish with garlic, coriander, chili, and serve with black vinegar.
tips: Add more five-spice or vinegar to taste for a stronger flavor.
Ngoh hiang and fried wantons are optional but traditional.
For extra richness, add a spoonful of lard to the gravy.
recipes.source: Adapted from Singapore hawker and home cook recipes.
recipes.origin: Lor Mee is a Hokkien dish, now a staple at Singapore hawker centers.

recipes.name: Chinese Rojak
recipes.description: A beloved Singaporean hawker salad of fresh fruits, vegetables, and youtiao tossed in a sweet, tangy, and savory prawn paste sauce, topped with crushed peanuts.

salad.jicama (bangkuang): 1 small, peeled and cut into sticks
salad.youtiao (fried dough sticks): 2, toasted and cut into bite-sized pieces

steps: Prepare Sauce: In a bowl, mix shrimp paste, tamarind paste, sugar, lime juice, and chili paste. Add water as needed to make a thick, pourable sauce. Adjust sweetness and tanginess to taste.
Assemble Salad: In a large bowl, combine pineapple, cucumber, jicama, apple/guava, bean sprouts, youtiao, and tofu (if using). Pour sauce over and toss well to coat all ingredients.
Serve: Transfer to a serving plate. Sprinkle generously with crushed peanuts and sesame seeds. Serve immediately.
tips: Toast youtiao and tau pok for extra crunch.
Add more chili for a spicier version.
Use a mix of fruits and vegetables for best texture and flavor.
recipes.source: Adapted from Singapore hawker and home cook recipes.
recipes.origin: Chinese Rojak is a popular street food salad in Singapore and Malaysia.

recipes.name: Penang Char Kway Teow
recipes.description: A Penang hawker legend: flat rice noodles stir-fried over high heat with prawns, Chinese sausage, eggs, bean sprouts, and chives in a savory, smoky sauce.
steps: Mix all sauce ingredients in a bowl and set aside.
Heat lard/oil in a wok over high heat until smoking. Add prawns and Chinese sausage, stir-fry 30 seconds.
Add garlic and fish cake, stir-fry briefly. Push to one side, add eggs and scramble.
Add noodles, pour sauce over, and toss to coat. Add bean sprouts, chives, and cockles (if using). Stir-fry quickly, pausing to let noodles sear for wok hei.
Add chili paste if desired. Serve immediately, garnished with extra chives.
tips: Use a well-seasoned wok and high heat for authentic wok hei.
Do not over-stir; let noodles char slightly for best flavor.
Cockles are traditional but optional.
recipes.source: Adapted from Penang hawker and home cook recipes.
recipes.origin: Penang Char Kway Teow is a signature street food of Penang, Malaysia, and beloved in Singapore.

recipes.name: White Bee Hoon
recipes.description: A comforting Singapore zi char and hawker favorite: silky rice vermicelli braised in a light, savory seafood broth with prawns, squid, vegetables, and egg.

main.cornstarch: 1 tsp, mixed with 2 tbsp water (for thickening)

steps: Heat oil in a wok. Sauté garlic until fragrant. Add prawns, squid, and fish cake, stir-fry until just cooked. Remove and set aside.
In the same wok, add more oil if needed. Add carrot and choy sum, stir-fry briefly.
Add chicken stock, soy sauce, fish sauce, Shaoxing wine, and white pepper. Bring to a boil.
Add soaked bee hoon and simmer until noodles absorb some broth and are tender.
Return seafood and fish cake to the wok. Drizzle in beaten egg and swirl gently to form egg ribbons.
Thicken with cornstarch slurry if desired. Adjust seasoning to taste.
Serve hot, garnished with fried shallots, spring onions, and a squeeze of calamansi lime.
tips: Use fresh seafood for best flavor.
Do not overcook bee hoon; it should remain silky and not mushy.
Add more stock for a soupier version.
recipes.source: Adapted from Sembawang White Bee Hoon and Singapore zi char recipes.
recipes.origin: White Bee Hoon is a modern Singapore zi char classic, made famous by Sembawang White Bee Hoon.
